comments.commentBody: I am a working class white that voted Hillary.  Trump does NOT speak for me.

Some popular vote data from Wikipedia (2008 and 2012 results) and the NYT 2016. Johnson vote count from heavy.com. Tells an interesting story for both the Democratic voting pattern (steadily trending down) and the Republican one (holding basically steady). Love to hear the NYT take on this.

Popular vote 2008
69,498,516 Obama
59,948,323 McCain

Popular vote 2012
65,915,795 Obama
60,933,504 Romney
~1,200,000 Johnson

Popular vote 2016
59,861,038 Clinton
59,638,006 Trump
4,042,291 Johnson

Trump won because he was he created a reality that suited him and convinced people to buy into it. He's been doing it his whole life. He knows that once he gets you to believe something outlandish, you'll cling to your faith in him so as not to feel like a fool.

Any candidate who even attempts to address reality will be at a disadvantage, because the real world does not allow neat solutions. HRC didn't even realize that she had to sell reality to the American people, and so she focused on nitty gritty policy that would lead to small but genuine economic improvement. You'd never sell cars that way and apparently you can't sell the presidency that way either.
I voted for Clinton, but it's clear that the Democrats were over-confident that the era of the white majority had ended. They miscalculated badly.
The Republican Party sees this election as a mandate, but the mandate is for the party of Trump and not the Republican Party.
Congratulations, President Trump.

So what is the point of the non-stop horse race and "big data" coverage in the media when you consistently get everything wrong?

"Trump will never win!" Then he won.
"Sanders has no chance!" Then he did.
"99% chance Clinton wins Michigan!" Then she lost, TWICE.

The Obama coalition had three main planks: minority voters, young voters, and working-class white union voters. Young voters and to a lesser extent union voters are less represented in Democratic Party membership (they skew Independent), but they're still absolutely ESSENTIAL to a Democratic victory in a general election.

One candidate in the Democratic primaries was able to unite two of these groups, but because of their underrepresentation in Party membership (and a vigorous effort by the Party to rig the contest) that candidate lost. This is supposed to be the function of these so-called "expert" Superdelegates. It was obvious what was going to happen when a candidate with zero appeal beyond minority voters walked into an electorate that's still 72% white.

One thing's clear: the Superdelegates truly serve no purpose, and are quite probably a destructive force. When push came to shove they put personal feelings and fundraising debts over the good of the Party and the country. It's time to get rid of them.

Overlay the Economic Innovations Group's "Distressed Communities" map with the NYTimes map that shows which states went red or blue and voila! Damn good fit. When 50% of new businesses formed since the end of the Great Recession were in only 20 counties in the entire country, then lots of people are left behind. Those places are concentrated on the west and east coasts - Hillary country.  Headlines that proclaim economic recovery fall flat when it's never you or your town ... when you have lost significant buying power .... when your home has not regained it's pre 2008 value .... when your college educated kid is working a job that does not require a college degree. Trump's victory was not so surprising after all.

This reporter needs to take a course in basic geography. Pennsylvania is NOT a Midwestern state, God-forbid. It may have behaved politically as one, but most times it is not.
Unfortunately, the rural parts of the state are as backward as Iowa and even worse, Indiana. Despicable.

Of course, the one-third of Latino votes and 13% of African-American male votes didn't hurt, but that's not really on-point. So never mind.

Anyway, before I forget: working-class white men! Definitely a problem!

Why Trump Won: Inestimable Stupidity of the Electorate
- end of story.

It's all about the last gasp of white privilege, desperate to make a last stand, knowing it's demographically a lost cause.  Reminds me a little of Israel.  Just a visceral reaction to the eclipse of a longstanding certainty.
If I were writing this piece, I'd  say "we screwed up big time."  Short and to the point.

Nonsense.  I have a doctorate and many well-educated friends.  We all voted for Trump.  It's not just "working-class whites."  It was fear of a Clinton administration.  We'd like to see our children grow up free of more wars and the threat of a nuclear one in particular.  The Clintons are dangerous; they're corrupt; it's time for them to fade into the shadows with their ill-gotten millions-- like their business and special-favor dealings.

Maybe not just working-class white men were the voters. How about well-off, comfortable older couples who want to keep their comforts, the maid, the yard boy and the nice house? There seemed to be quite a few of these folks in Florida.

Illegal immigrants will be referred to as illegal immigrants.
Americans safety will come before Muslim sensitivity.
BLM won't have a seat at the table with the President and their rioting will not be tolerated and rewarded.
The right for people who think they are women but biologically men to use female only areas will not be a top national concern.
The ability to easily destroy careers and reputations by calling someone racist, sexism, Islamaphobic, and/or xenophobic for any slight no matter how minor, has probably seen it's heyday.

There are some of the positive things of the Trump victory I've been able to think up. I say this as someone who respect trans rights and did not vote Trump.

You thought G.W. Bush was bad? You thought just because he ran the country into the ground and almost destroyed the world economy that it was just an aberration? You thought that your Social Security was safe? You think that there will never be another 9/11 with Trump at the controls and a Republican House & Senate (just like G.W. Bush)? You think that "White Privilege" is SAFE? You think that there is nothing in his tax records that would indicate his business interests in Russia?

You weren't thinking at all and you "White Males" that voted this fool into office will rue the day you did so.

All these assumptions are based on exit polls and if we learned anything from this election that is that polling today is a very inexact science. Americans voted for Donald Trump and Americans voted for Hillary Clinton. Can't we leave it at that. This slicing and dicing of our country is extremely detrimental to our progress as a nation.

replies.commentBody: Sorry the "Devil" is not in the details on this one.

comments.commentBody: This election was not about how some white people voted, it's about who didn't vote, but acknowledging this fact is not PC. Look at the national vote totals of McCain '08, Romney '12 and Trump '16. McCain-59.9 million, Romney 60.9 and Trump 59.6. They all got the same group of people who have been voting Republican all along and didn't improve it at all. Hillary will probably (just barely) win the popular vote due to running it up in places like California but she under performed Obama by roughly 10 million votes in '08 and 5 mil in '12.  Look at Ohio, McCain-2.68 million, Romney 2.66, Trump-2.77 (all within 110K). Obama '12 2.83, Clinton '16 2.32, Hilary lost 500K in Ohio. Same is true in Wisconsin, Trump did roughly the same as Romney and McCain but Hillary lost 300K of Obama's vote. Now look at WI D-4, Gwen Moore's urban Milwaukee district. She lost 65K votes from '12 to '16. Paul Ryan in WI D-1 gained a few thousand votes over '12 but total voter turnout was down by nearly 50K, all Dem votes. I could go on and on about urban districts in Ohio and Pennsylvania as well. Trump did nothing magical, he got a usual Republican turnout. It was not enough to protect Obama's legacy (blacks) or the plight of illegal immigrants (Hispanics) to get minorities to come out and vote for an old white woman. That is the non PC lesson, not some white uprising or massive voting shift, it's minorities staying home and the numbers prove it. It's why we have over 30 Republican governors too.

Historians will look back at this election and attribute the widespread defection of low and middle income Caucasian support for the Democratic candidate to their party's embrace of market capitalism, free trade, globalism and increased immigration, which they viewed as counterproductive to their needs. Should Trump's populist theme of "America First" become synonymous with the GOP, the Democratic party may never recover this once reliable bloc of voters in the blue belt states that decided the outcome of this election.

All one needs to do is look across the Atlantic and examine the demise of the Labour party, which championed unrestricted immigration and social engineering policies that dramatically altered the UK's racial demographics at the expense of the working class and lower-income Britons whose votes they took for granted. With their once loyal voter base now allied with UKIP and the Conservatives, the Labour party is in ruins.

Today’s media love narrative, so here’s a story for you.

In 1994, California voters were asked to consider Proposition 187. This law would have prevented illegal immigrants from receiving public benefits. I was working for The San Bernardino (Calif.) Sun at the time, and I asked one of my colleagues who had a Hispanic surname if he was opposed to Proposition 187. Not at all. He was in favor of it, and he set me straight:

“I don’t want to live in a barrio!”

His grandparents may have been born in Mexico, but he was born in California. How many Americans want to live in a barrio?

There’s an old saying in journalism that a reporter is only as good as his or her sources. America’s national news media spend too much time talking to pollsters and each other. Instead of cultivating sources, they cultivate tribes and stereotypes.

Instead of name-calling in this campaign, we could have had a rational discussion about the decline of the economic vitality of rural America. When I worked in Ohio and Montana in the 70s, the towns and small cities there enjoyed a vibrant mix of agriculture, light industry and Main Street commerce. Today, the sense of microcosmic self-sufficiency and local pride that I and others felt back then is much weaker. But instead of identifying and solving this problem, we let a demagogue indulge our taste for blame.  We've been childish, and the result is the worst electoral outcome since 2000. After having behaved like children, will we suddenly be able to behave like adults?

Nate Cohn and the rest of the Upshot staff should be fired immediately for an incredibly poor job during this election.  I no longer have any confidence in the polling tools or credibility of those polled.  Individuals were either too embarrassed to admit that they would vote for the racist bigot, or the pollsters were astoundingly incompetent.  I, for one, will never read this portion of the paper again, and the Times might consider saving scarce revenue by eliminating this heartbreakingly misleading section.

Looks to me like Hillary non-enthusiasm cost about 5 million possibly critical votes nation wide compared to 2012 and 2008. I haven't done a detailed study state by state whether that would have made a difference but it certainly didn't help.

If those 5 million were like me, they saw a non choice between a conservative revival led by an ignorant, prevaricating, predatory boor and a dysfunctional, distracted Democratic presidency led by a magnet for suspicion and riven by incessant Republican investigations and stalling tactics, and decided to opt out.

replies.commentBody: I agree with your comments Anon. Canadian's watched this election with more interest than usual; mainly based on the fear of Trump becoming president. Unfortunately it is the uneducated white males who put Trump into the White House. Trump appealed to males who didn't understand the issues. It was like a bunch of drunk guys in a frat on a Saturday night voting for the loudest, most boorish person they could find. The American systems needs an overhaul. 600 days of campaigning is ridiculous. People loose site of what is important. In Canada we had a lengthy 11 week campaign. The most important issue of our time being that of climate change is going to be relegated to the back burner as the right wing close minded republicans take control. The state of the Earth will continue its downward spiral. The Grand Old Party needs to rebuild itself. It is not the 1800's anymore. It is time to become a Grand New Party and move forward and deal with the important issues today. Unfortunately that requires a global understanding of issues and considering uneducated whites put Trump into power I don't see things changing. Again the candidate with the most votes did not win. Good luck over the next four years.

comments.commentBody:
The rest of the world is aghast at this horrible person, while it is white American voters who have handed this train wreck the keys to the White House and have given the federal government to his complicit party. There is no quick fix to the problem of white voter miseducation and bigotry, but the first step is recognizing the problem. As a white person, I'm speaking to other caucasians. Let's get real. We are the biggest problem. Fixing this starts with us. Everyone plays a role, but we play the worst role. Sexism, homophobia, racism, religious intolerance and failure to affirm diversity. As hard as I try, the older I get and the more I learn, the more I realize times when I perpetuate these ills, even in subtle ways. In fact, it is usually when we think we have none of these traits that we are the worst of them. We are also probably the biggest contributors to destroying our planet. We have blood on our hands and it is time to look inward at what we are doing. So I'm committing today, to check myself, every morning, on all of these issues. Am I contributing to the problem? If so, how? I'm going to keep doing this until I can become carbon neutral and hopefully a better fellow human being.
Please join me.
